title: Marcus Blackmore in $400 million wipeout
text:
Blackmores shares have continued to slide in the wake of a poor full-year result as worries about its prospects in China worsen, with Rich Lister Marcus Blackmore suffering the most on paper because of his 23.1 per cent stake.

Mr Blackmore, who is still the interim chief executive, holds 4.01 million shares in the tightly held vitamins maker and in the past year the value of his holding has fallen on paper by $400 million.

Blackmores shares continued their decline on Monday, heading down 3.5 per cent to below $65. That compares with $163 in late August, 2018 when Mr Blackmore's stake was worth around $655 million. The stock was as high as $220 in early January, 2016 when the stake was worth $880 million.

Morgan Stanley analyst Niraj Shah has a 12-month price target of $84 on the shares, and said that de-stocking and channel disruption in the wake of changes in e-commerce regulations in China had been a major factor. A spike in sales of items such as Vitamin C from a bad flu season in Australia had also failed to materialise, the broker concluded.

Marcus Blackmore holds 23.1 per cent of Blackmores. Peter Rae

Mr Blackmore is the largest shareholder and has been trying to steady the ship.
description: A fading China vitamins miracle has been difficult to swallow for the largest shareholder in Blackmores in the past 12 months.
